subject: Coming up this Sunday on Reliable Sources
body:
CNN.com










Coming up this Sunday on Reliable Sources:

Multimedia Manifesto

Did NBC make a big
mistake in airing the troubling, violent pictures and videos of
Virginia Tech gunman Seung-Hui Cho?  Since the package landed
at 30 Rock and led the Nightly News Wednesday, a vicious debate
has erupted and an angry public has convinced many of the media
outlets who followed suit to scrub the images from their
broadcasts.  We'll go right to the decision-maker, NBC News
President Steve Capus, and get reaction from talk radio hosts
Hugh Hewitt and Bill Press, and the Philadelphia Inquirer's
Gail Shister. 

A Safe Distance

Where
should we draw the line between aggressively covering a story
and invading the privacy of a community?  As some students and
families ask for room to grieve, have reporters allowed them
enough space?	We'll talk to three reporters who covered the
story on the ground in Blacksburg, Sharyn Alfonsi of CBS News,
Gene Robinson of the Washington Post, and CNN's Soledad
O'Brien.

New Media, New Questions

Jamal Albarghouti's dramatic video, captured with his cell
phone, instantly provided an eyewitness account of the Virginia
Tech incident to the world.  What are the promises and
potential pitfalls of having so many people armed 24/7 with a
video camera?  

Plus, MySpace and Facebook
helped drive the coverage, giving reporters and bloggers
intimate portraits of some victims, and generating backlash
from students who just want the press to back off.  We'll get a
new media perspective from Townhall's Mary Katharine Ham and
Jeff Jarvis of Buzzmachine.com.

Join us this Sunday
and every Sunday at 10am ET / 7am PT for our critical look at
the media!
